Ten students are to be arranged in a new chemistry lab. The chemistry

so that one is directly behind the other. Then the rest of the
students may be arranged in8!=403208! = 40\hspace{0.15em}3208!=40320ways.

\answer{(10)(8!) = 403\hspace{0.15em}200}\end{aligned}(10)(8!)=403200​​Hugo and Leo may be arranged in the lab first in(8)(2)=16(8)(2) = 16(8)(2)=16ways

In this case, the number of ways the ten students may be

\end{align*}k2​​=6×5!=720​The total will bek=k1+k2k = k_1 + k_2k=k1​+k2​.k=1440+720k=2160\begin{align*}

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
Julie works at a book store and has nine books to display on the main
shelf of the store. Four of the books are non-fiction and five are
fiction. Each book is different. Determine the number of possible ways
Julie can line up the nine books on the main shelf, given thatthe non-fiction books should stand together;[2]the non-fiction books should stand together on either end;[2]the non-fiction books should stand together and do not stand on
either end.[2]
list.markScheme:
Letkkkbe the number of possible ways that the 9 books can be
ordered with the 4 non-fiction books being arranged together.To findkkk, we can consider a two steps process. First, we can
treat the 4 non-fiction books as a single item, and so there are6!6!6!permutations of the 5 fiction books and the block of
non-fiction books. After that, we can arrange the non-fiction books
in4!4!4!different ways. Thus, by the multiplication rule, we getk=6!×4!=17280\begin{aligned}
k &= 6!\times 4! \hspace{0.3em} \\[6pt]
&\answer{= 17\hspace{0.15em}280}\end{aligned}k​=6!×4!=17280​​Letmmmbe the number of possible ways that the non-fiction books
can stand together on either end. There are222ways in which the
non-fiction books can be on one end, and5!5!5!ways to order the
fiction books next to them. Finally, the non-fiction books can be
ordered in4!4!4!ways. Hence, we findm=2×5!×4!=5760\begin{aligned}
m &=  2\times 5! \times 4! \hspace{1.0em} \\[6pt]
&\answer{= 5\hspace{0.15em}760}\end{aligned}m​=2×5!×4!=5760​​Letnnnbe the number of possible ways that the non-fiction books
can stand together and do not stand on either end.Using the results found in parts (a)-(b), we findn=k−m=11520\begin{aligned}
\hspace{3.8em} n &= k-m \\[6pt]
&\answer{= 11\hspace{0.15em}520}\end{aligned}n​=k−m=11520​​

Bella:Aria's cubicleBella's cubicle13, 5, 624, 631, 4, 542, 3, 651, 361, 2, 4Thus, there are161616ways of placing Aria and Bella in cubicles that
do not share a boundary.After that, Charlotte can be placed in any of the 4 remaining

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
Sophie and Ella play a game. They each have five cards showing roman
numerals I, V, X, L, C. Sophie lays her cards face
up on the table in order I, V, X, L, C as shown in
the following diagram.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39c87612-7c32-40b7-9150-936d318630c0/images/b4f00281-ba44-44fd-8ba3-6710c101617e/8c2117a8771870dcd1b10ba85dbc123753724df8.svg)

Ella shuffles her cards and lays them face down on the table. She then
turns them over one by one to see if her card
matches with Sophie's card directly above. Sophie wins ifnomatches occur; otherwise Ella wins.Show that the probability that Sophie wins the game is1130\dfrac{11}{30}3011​.[6]Sophie and Ella repeat their game so that they play a total of909090times. Let the discrete random
variableXXXrepresent the number of times Sophie wins.Determine:the mean ofXXX;the variance ofXXX.[5]
list.markScheme:
We have

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39c87612-7c32-40b7-9150-936d318630c0/images/ee00d62c-2dc7-40c3-89ae-032bc78b6386/5557f2430f2b6a1d2ae2b382374192f4abd645a4.svg)

There are5!=1205! = 1205!=120possible ways to lay down five cards in order
on the table.Hence the number of possible ways to lay down five cards with no
matches is120−(45+20+10+0+1)=120−76=44\begin{aligned}
120 - (45+20+10+0+1) &= 120 - 76 \hspace{1.8em} \\[8pt]
&= 44\end{aligned}120−(45+20+10+0+1)​=120−76=44​Hence the probability that Sophie wins the game
isP(Sophie wins)=44120=1130\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2em} \mathrm{P}(\text{Sophie wins}) &= \dfrac{44}{120} \\[8pt]
&\answer{= \dfrac{11}{30}}\end{aligned}P(Sophie wins)​=12044​=3011​​​SinceX∼B(90,11/30)X \sim \mathrm{B}(90,11/30)X∼B(90,11/30), we getE[X]=np=90×1130=33\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{E}[X] &= np \\[6pt]
&= 90\times\dfrac{11}{30} \hspace{3.3em} \\[8pt]
&\answer{= 33}\end{aligned}E[X]​=np=90×3011​=33​​Using the formula for the variance ofX∼B(90,11/30)X \sim \mathrm{B}(90,11/30)X∼B(90,11/30), we obtainVar(X)=np(1−p)=90×1130×[1−1130]=20.9\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.75em} \mathrm{Var}(X) &= np(1-p) \\[6pt]
&= 90\times\dfrac{11}{30}\times\hspace{-0.1em}\bigg[1 - \dfrac{11}{30}\bigg] \\[6pt]
&\answer{= 20.9}\end{aligned}Var(X)​=np(1−p)=90×3011​×[1−3011​]=20.9​​

&= 14! - 10!\times4\times3!\times11\times10 - 10!\times4!\times11 \\[12pt]
&\answer{= 7.66\times10^{10}}\end{aligned}n​=14!−10!×(34​)×3!×(211​)×2!−10!×(44​)×4!×(111​)×1!=14!−10!×4×3!×11×10−10!×4!×11=7.66×1010​​
